items.label: thm-limit-is-weak-solution
items.title: Limit Points are Weak Solutions to the Stationary Mean-Field PDE
items.content:
686: :label: thm-limit-is-weak-solution
687: 
688: Let $\{\mu_{N_k}\}$ be any subsequence of the marginal measures that converges weakly to a limit point $\mu_\infty$. Then $\mu_\infty$ is a weak solution to the stationary mean-field coupled system:
689: 
690: $$
691: L^\dagger \rho_0 - c(z)\rho_0 + S[\rho_0] + B[\rho_0, m_{d,\infty}] = 0
692: 
693: $$
694: 
695: with the equilibrium condition:
696: 
697: $$
698: k_{\text{killed}}[\rho_0] = \lambda_{\text{rev}} m_{d,\infty}
699: 
700: $$

items.content:
1449: :label: thm-uniqueness-hormander
1450: 
1451: Let $L$ be a second-order operator of the form:
1452: 
1453: $$
1454: L = \sum_{i=1}^{m} X_i^2 + X_0
1455: 
1456: $$
1457: 
1458: where $X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_m$ are smooth vector fields on a manifold $M$. If the Lie algebra generated by $\{X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_m\}$ spans the tangent space $T_z M$ at every point $z \in M$, then $L$ is hypoelliptic.

items.content:
1547: :label: thm-uniqueness-hypoelliptic-regularity
1548:

1550: 
1551: $$
1552: -\mathcal{L}_{\text{lin}} u = f
1553: 
1554: $$
1555:

1557: 
1558: $$
1559: \|u\|_{H^1_w} \le C_{\text{hypo}} \|f\|_{L^2_w}

items.label: thm-uniqueness-contraction-solution-operator
items.title: Contraction Property of the Solution Operator on an Invariant Ball
items.content:
1713: :label: thm-uniqueness-contraction-solution-operator
1714: 
1715: Let $R^* > 0$ be the radius from Lemma [](#lem-uniqueness-fixed-point-boundedness) and define the closed ball:
1716: 
1717: $$
1718: \mathcal{P}_R := \mathcal{P} \cap \{\rho \in H^1_w(\Omega) : \|\rho\|_{H^1_w} \le R^*\}
1719: 
1720: $$
1721: 
1722: There exists a choice of parameters (specifically, sufficiently large kinetic diffusion $\sigma_v^2$) such that the solution operator $\mathcal{T}: \mathcal{P}_R \to \mathcal{P}_R$ is a strict contraction on this ball. That is, there exists $\kappa(R^*) \in (0, 1)$ such that:
1723: 
1724: $$
1725: \|\mathcal{T}[\rho_1] - \mathcal{T}[\rho_2]\|_{H^1_w} \le \kappa(R^*) \|\rho_1 - \rho_2\|_{H^1_w}
1726: 
1727: $$

items.label: thm-qsd-marginals-are-tight-summary
items.title: The Sequence of Marginals $\{\mu_N\}$ is Tight (Summary)
items.section: ## **6. Justification of the Mean-Field Model: Propagation of Chaos and the Thermodynamic Limit**
items.raw_directive:
1966: The first step in proving convergence is to show that the sequence of measures $\{\mu_N\}$ is pre-compact in the space of probability measures on $\Omega$. This property, known as **tightness**, guarantees the existence of at least one convergent subsequence, ensuring that probability mass does not "escape to infinity" in the limit.

items.label: thm-limit-is-weak-solution-summary
items.title: Limit Points are Weak Solutions to the Stationary Mean-Field PDE (Summary)
items.section: ## **6. Justification of the Mean-Field Model: Propagation of Chaos and the Thermodynamic Limit**
items.raw_directive:
2011: Tightness guarantees that at least one convergent subsequence exists. This section proves that any such limit point must be a weak solution to the stationary mean-field PDE. This is the core of the propagation of chaos argument, where we demonstrate that the discrete, empirical interactions of the N-particle system converge to the continuous, integral-based functionals of the mean-field model.

items.label: thm-thermodynamic-limit
items.title: Convergence of Macroscopic Observables (The Thermodynamic Limit)
items.content:
2128: :label: thm-thermodynamic-limit
2129: 
2130: Let $\rho_0$ be the unique stationary solution to the mean-field PDE. Let $\phi: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ be any bounded, continuous function (a "macroscopic observable").
2131: 
2132: Then, the average value of this observable in the N-particle quasi-stationary state converges to the expected value of the observable in the mean-field stationary state:
2133: 
2134: $$
2135: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{QSD}} \left[ \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \phi(z_i) \right] = \int_\Omega \phi(z) \rho_0(z) dz
items.section: ## **6. Justification of the Mean-Field Model: Propagation of Chaos and the Thermodynamic Limit**
items.raw_directive:
2125: The convergence of the entire sequence $\{\mu_N\}$ to a unique limit is the formal statement of **propagation of chaos**. A direct and powerful corollary of this result is the existence of a valid thermodynamic limit for the system. This means that macroscopic, intensive quantities calculated from the finite-N equilibrium state converge to the corresponding quantities calculated from the mean-field equilibrium state as $N \to \infty$.
2126: 
2127: :::{prf:theorem} Convergence of Macroscopic Observables (The Thermodynamic Limit)
2128: :label: thm-thermodynamic-limit
2129: 
2130: Let $\rho_0$ be the unique stationary solution to the mean-field PDE. Let $\phi: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ be any bounded, continuous function (a "macroscopic observable").
2131: 
2132: Then, the average value of this observable in the N-particle quasi-stationary state converges to the expected value of the observable in the mean-field stationary state:
2133: 
2134: $$
2135: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{QSD}} \left[ \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \phi(z_i) \right] = \int_\Omega \phi(z) \rho_0(z) dz
